meanings.definition: To release air or gas from (something)
meanings.sent1: I watched the mechanic deflate the tire before fixing it.
meanings.sent2: After the party, I had to deflate all the balloons.
meanings.sent3: Trying to deflate a balloon by sitting on it is not as easy as it looks!
meanings.sent4: Her harsh words seemed to deflate his ego like a popped balloon.
meanings.sent5: The sound of air rushing out as I deflate the balloon is always satisfying.

meanings.definition: To reduce in size, importance, or value
meanings.sent1: The sales of the company started to deflate after the scandal.
meanings.sent2: Leaving the cake out too long caused it to deflate and lose its fluffiness.
meanings.sent3: His exaggerated stories always deflate the truth.
meanings.sent4: The hopes of winning began to deflate as the game progressed.
meanings.sent5: The bubble slowly started to deflate as the excitement faded away.

meanings.definition: To cause (someone) to feel less confident or proud
meanings.sent1: Her harsh criticism seemed to deflate his enthusiasm for the project.
meanings.sent2: The unexpected failure deflated his confidence in his abilities.
meanings.sent3: His over-the-top boasting always ends up deflating his own image.
meanings.sent4: The rejection letter seemed to deflate all his hopes for the future.
meanings.sent5: The coach's harsh words deflated the team's spirits before the big game.
